>
[Battle Saddle](/Weapons.aspx?ID=271)
</title>

<traits>
<trait label="Parry" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=190" />
<trait label="Sweep" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=194" />
<trait label="Vehicular" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=493" />
</traits>

<column gap="tiny">

<row gap="tiny">**Source** [Treasure Vault](/Sources.aspx?ID=191) pg. 26 <sup>1.1</sup></row>

<row gap="medium">
**Price** 6 gp

**Damage** 1d8 S

**Bulk** 2
</row>

<row gap="medium">
**Hands** 2

</row>

<row gap="medium">
**Category** Martial

**Group** [Axe](/WeaponGroups.aspx?ID=1)
</row>

</column>

---

The battle saddle is a special saddle for a mount that has two large, winglike blades. These blades normally lie flat alongside the saddle, providing additional protection for the rider, but they can be deployed with a tug on the reins to slash at enemies adjacent to the mount. When using a battle saddle to parry, you can decide whether the circumstance bonus to AC applies to you or to your mount.

<title level="2">Critical Specialization Effects</title>

<row gap="tiny">**Source** [Core Rulebook](/Sources.aspx?ID=1) pg. 283 <sup>4.0</sup></row>

Certain feats, class features, weapon runes, and other effects can grant you additional benefits when you make a Strike with certain weapons and get a critical success. This is called a critical specialization effect. The exact effect depends on which weapon group your weapon belongs to, as listed below. You can always decide not to add the critical specialization effect of your weapon.

[Click here for the full rules on Critical Specialization Effects](/Rules.aspx?ID=235).
